summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan denying Ghislaine Maxwell's request to subpoena materials from the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP. The request sought a victim's diary, a pair of boots, and original photographs, which the court found were either not relevant, speculative, or would be made available through other means.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, seeking to subpoena evidence including a victim's diary, boots, and photographs.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge who issued the order denying Maxwell's subpoena requests.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and co-conspirator; mentioned as having given gifts to a victim and spent time with her.

connections.description: Referred to together as allegedly giving gifts to a minor victim and being involved in the same incidents.
Maxwell is the defendant accused of crimes against this minor victim, who is the subject of the subpoena requests.
Epstein is mentioned as having spent time with the victim and given her gifts.

events.title: Court Denies Initial Subpoena Request
events.description: The court denied Ghislaine Maxwell's initial request for authorization to serve a subpoena to Boies Schiller Flexner LLP.

events.title: Government Submits Views on Subpoena
events.description: The Government submitted its views on Maxwell's subpoena requests to the court.

events.title: Defendant Files Response
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell filed a response to the Government's views on the subpoena requests.

events.title: Minor Victim-2's Trip to New York
events.description: Referenced in the victim's diary as a trip where she spent time with Jeffrey Epstein and visited his residence.

keyFacts: The court denied Ghislaine Maxwell's request to subpoena the entire teenage diary of 'Minor Victim-2,' finding the request a 'fishing expedition' aimed at impeachment, which is not proper under Rule 17(c).

The Government and the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP both represented that the victim's diary does not mention Ghislaine Maxwell and that the victim stopped writing in it shortly after meeting Jeffrey Epstein.

Maxwell also sought a pair of black boots allegedly given to the victim by her and Epstein; the Government stated the FBI would obtain them and make them available to the defense, rendering the subpoena moot.
Requests for original photographs were partially moot as the Government would provide access, and otherwise denied as the defense failed to establish relevance beyond potential impeachment.
The order underscores the high bar for issuing Rule 17(c) subpoenas, requiring a showing of specific relevance that goes beyond mere impeachment of witnesses.
